verses.text: Blessed be the LORD, my rock, who trains my hands for battle and my fingers for war.
verses.comment: The opening verse acknowledges God's strength as the foundation and source of victory, echoing Psalm 18 where David credits the LORD for preparing him for warfare. The term 'my rock' prefigures Christ as our firm foundation (cf. Matt. 7:24-25).

verses.text: He is my steadfast love and my fortress, my strong tower and deliverer, my shield in whom I take refuge, who subdues peoples under me.
verses.comment: Multiple titles for God reflect His protective and saving roles. 'Subdues peoples' also foreshadows Christ's ultimate kingship and victory over the powers of this world (cf. 1 Cor. 15:25).

verses.text: O LORD, what is man, that you regard him, or the son of man, that you think of him?
verses.comment: This verse humbles humanity before God's transcendence, yet it also prophetically points to Christ, the Son of Man, in Heb. 2:6, underscoring God's intimate concern and the dignity bestowed on mankind.

verses.text: Man is like a breath; his days are like a passing shadow.
verses.comment: Echoes the theme of human life's fleeting nature, found elsewhere in Psalms and wisdom literature. This calls us toward valuing eternal things and points to the hope in Christ beyond temporal existence.

verses.text: Bow your heavens, O LORD, and come down! Touch the mountains so they smoke!
verses.comment: This dramatic plea for divine intervention echoes God's appearance at Sinai (Ex. 19:18), foreshadowing both the Incarnation (God becoming present among His people) and the coming power in the Gospel.

verses.text: Flash forth lightning and scatter them; send out your arrows and rout them.
verses.comment: God's power over the nations is expressed through storm imagery, as in Ps. 18 and Ex. 9. It reveals God as the active defender of His servants, which ultimately points to Christ's victory over evil.

verses.text: Stretch out your hand from on high; rescue me and deliver me from the many waters, from the hand of foreigners,
verses.comment: The 'many waters' symbolize overwhelming danger. God's hand intervening from above has sacramental overtones, recalling God's saving acts throughout history.

verses.text: whose mouths speak lies and whose right hand is a hand of falsehood.
verses.comment: God's people are threatened not only by physical dangers, but also deception and falsehood—poignant reminders of the need for truth and integrity within the people of God.

verses.text: I will sing a new song to you, O God; upon a ten-stringed harp I will play to you,
verses.comment: Singing a 'new song' is associated with God's new acts of salvation. The musical worship here prefigures the ongoing sacrificial praise of God's people, both on earth and in heaven (cf. Rev. 5:9).

verses.text: who gives victory to kings, who rescues David his servant from the deadly sword.
verses.comment: The reference to David highlights God's faithfulness to His chosen king, prefiguring the Davidic covenant fulfilled in Christ, the eternal King (cf. Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: Rescue me and deliver me from the hand of foreigners, whose mouths speak lies and whose right hand is a hand of falsehood.
verses.comment: Repeats v8, emphasizing the importance of truth and deliverance. In spiritual interpretation, the foreign adversaries represent worldly temptations and sin.

verses.text: May our sons be like plants grown up in their youth, our daughters like corner pillars, sculpted for a palace;
verses.comment: Imagery of flourishing children symbolizing the hope of future generations. The sculpted pillars image reflects the dignity and vocation of women in God’s design for family and worship.

verses.text: May our barns be filled with all kinds of produce; may our flocks multiply by thousands and ten thousands in our fields;
verses.comment: Material blessing is a sign of God's favor but also points beyond itself to spiritual abundance in Christ. All good things are gifts—suggesting a sacramental worldview.

verses.text: may our cattle be heavy with young, may there be no breach or exile, nor cry of distress in our streets;
verses.comment: Completeness and peace are the marks of the righteous community. The desire for 'no breach or exile' can be read as longing for unity and order in God's household.

verses.text: Blessed are the people to whom such things happen; blessed are the people whose God is the LORD.
verses.comment: True happiness is found in belonging to God. The dual blessings recall both earthly prosperity and spiritual fulfillment—anticipating Christ's teaching on the blessedness of those who belong to the Kingdom (cf. Matt. 5:3-12).
